title: Protocol to analyze antitumor immunity of orthotopic injection and spontaneous murine high-grade glioma models using flow cytometry and single-cell RNA sequencing
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Section 1. Induction of spontaneous brain tumor model.
Section 2. Induction of intracranial injection model.
Section 3. Isolation of single cells from brain tumor microenvironment.
Section 4. Single cell-RNA sequencing analysis for immune cells from the brain tumor microenvironment.
Section 5. Flow cytometric analysis for immune cells from the brain tumor microenvironment.
Section 1. Induction of the spontaneous brain tumor model
Timing: 20 min
This section details how to induce the spontaneous brain tumor model.
Anesthetize pups via hypothermia by placing them on ice for at least 5 min (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1886-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Induction of spontaneous brain tumors via injection of plasmid DNA into the brain
(A) Hypothermal anesthesia setup for pups.
(B) Plasmid DNA solution mixed with Fast Green.
(C) The original (a) and the tip-removed (b) micropipettes.
(D) A micropipette connected with a silicon tube.
(E) A micropipette tip loaded with the plasmid DNA solution.
(F) Injection point at approximately 1/3 the length of the virtual line between the right eye and lambda.
(G) Confirmation of plasmid DNA injection into the lateral ventricle via lightening brain with lamp.
(H) A Tweezer electrode.
(I) Transfecting plasmid DNA into the brain via electroporation.
(J) Confocal microscopy (red: tdTomato+ tumors; DAPI: nuclei) of brain tumor tissue sections from the spontaneous brain tumor model in mice with a hunched posture (20 weeks). Zoomed image of the border of the tumor tissue is shown on the right. Scale bar = 1000 μm (left) and 100 μm (right).
Prepare sgRNA-Trp53/Pten-Cas9-Cre plasmid DNA inserted into the brain of 0–2-day-old pups.
Dilute plasmid DNA stock to 2 μg/μL in ddH2O.
Add Fast green (10% final volume) to plasmid DNA solution (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Note: Fast Green powder is used to visually confirm injection of DNA into the brain.

Prepare a piece of parafilm in order to place several droplets (1 μL per droplet) of plasmid DNA solution.
Prepare the micropipette for injection.
Slightly cut off the tip of a micropipette using forceps before loading the droplet (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
Connect the other side of a micropipette to a silicon tube for blowing out the DNA (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D).
Bring the micropipette tip to the droplet and roll it until the droplet is completely loaded (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]E).
Inject the plasmid DNA into the lateral ventricle of the brain.
Make a virtual line between the right eye and lambda.
Make the insertion point at about 1/3 the length of this line from the lambda (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]F).
Insert the micropipette tip into this position at a depth of 2 μm from the skull.
Extrude the DNA by blowing the other side of the silicon tube.
Confirm the injection by using Fast Green to show the shape of the lateral ventricle (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]G).
Note: Fast Green staining can be visualized better by illuminating the brain with a lamp.
Apply an electric pulse to the animal after successful injection of plasmid DNA.
Prepare an electroporator and a tweezer electrode (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]H).
Set the condition of pulse: 100 V, 50 ms, separated by 950 ms intervals, 5 times.
Soak the electrode tips with PBS to make electrical pulses that pass through the brain tissue.
Hold the brain with the wet electrode and apply the pulses (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]I).
Positive electrode: ahead of the eye.
Negative electrode: the opposite position on the ventricle side.
Return the pups to the cage.
Tumor formation can be confirmed by checking for tdTomato-expressing cells (Lee et al., 2018[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]) (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]J).
Section 2. Induction of the brain tumor injection model
Timing: 30 min

This section explains how to induce the orthotopic syngeneic murine brain tumor model by injecting GL261 cells.
Note: The injection site could be critical, so the mouse head should be fixed during the experiments.
Note: Drilling the skull and injecting cells can cause bleeding, which could affect the immune response and tumor formation. It is important to avoid blood vessels during the experiments. Even though the injection speed could vary depending on preferences, the injection should be performed as slow as possible to avoid tissue damage.
Note: Cell type and number can vary depending on preferences and purpose, and thus should be optimized by users. Please refer to Oh et al., 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6].
Prepare the mouse for stereotaxic surgery.
Anesthetize a mouse with isoflurane.
Turn on a heating pad.
Fix the mouse on a stereotaxic instrument which connects the anesthesia machine that administers isoflurane.
Arrange the insertion position.
Sterilize the skin of the head.
Cut the skin along the midline of the head (∼1 cm) with a surgical scissor.
Peel off the mucus on the skull with a cotton swab.
Fix a sterile pen on the syringe holder and point to the bregma to mark locations.
Set the position of the bregma as zero for the x- and y-axes.
Move to 2.0 mm anterior and 2.0 mm right, and mark this location with the pen (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1886-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Schematic image of stereotaxic surgery for the injection brain tumor model
For the injection brain tumor model, a mouse is fixed on a stereotaxic instrument and the injection point is 2.0 mm anterior and 2.0 mm right from the bregma of the brain. Several blood vessels may be present around the injection point.
Make a hole in the insertion position with a micro drill.

Note: Excessive drilling can cause tissue damage and bleeding, so be careful to only drill on the skull.
Inject GL261 cells at the insertion position.
Load a Hamilton syringe with prepared GL261 cells in a volume of 2 μL.
Move the syringe to the hole and touch the tip of needle to the tissue surface, setting this location as zero for the z-axis.
Move the syringe down to 3.5 mm inferior and wait for 1 min.
Move the syringe up to 0.5 mm superior (3.0 mm inferior from the surface).
Inject the GL261 cells at a rate of 0.4 μL/min for 5 min with the syringe infusion pump (Total injection volume: 2 μL per mouse).
Remove the syringe carefully and slowly.
Fill the hole with bonding material mixed with beads.
Tighten the skin around the wound with surgical suture thread.
Place the mouse back into its cage.
Section 3. Isolation of single cells from the brain tumor microenvironment
Timing: ∼3 h
This section explains how to isolate single cells from tissues.
Note: Single cell isolation methods can differ. Here we used enzymatic tissue dissociation.
Cardiac perfusion.
Euthanize the mouse by CO2 inhalation.
Load 10 mL of PBS into a 10 mL-syringe and then attach a 24-gauge needle.
Place and fix the mouse onto the surgery area.
Incise the ventral side of the skin and snip the thoracic cavity.
Note: Be careful to avoid scratching the heart, lung, or veins.
Pin both sides of the ribs to make room for the needle injection to the heart.
Place the needle of the syringe containing PBS onto the left ventricle and make a small hole on the right atrium through which blood flows.
Push the syringe plunger with moderate force.

Note: Perfusion is important to harvest cells while excluding circulating cells. Confirm whether the redness of the liver has faded after the perfusion.
Harvest the brain tissue.
Cut the skin of the head along the midline from the neck to the eyes.
Hold the skin open on both sides.
Cut the skull along the sagittal suture beginning from the brainstem.
Note: Be careful not to damage the brain tissue.
Remove both halves of the skull from the head.
Pull the brain out and place it into cold DMEM.
Digest the brain tissue with enzymes.
Prepare an enzyme mixture containing 2 mg/mL Collagenase IV and 30 μg/mL DNase I in 5 mL of isolation buffer.
Sterilize a razor with 100% ethanol.
Place the brain tissue on a 60-mm petri dish.
Chop it finely with the sterilized razor in the dish.
Note: Keep samples moist with cold DPBS.
Transfer the tissue pieces into a new 15-mL tube with 5 mL of enzyme mixture.
Note: Large tissues may block the pipette end. Instead, large tissues could be transferred by forceps.
Incubate at 37°C for 30 min in a shaking water bath.
After incubation, centrifuge the tube at 4°C, 440 rcf for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet with 5 mL of the dissociation buffer.
Incubate at 37°C for 5 min in a shaking water bath.
Dissociate cells from the tissue suspension.
Prepare a 60-mm petri dish, a syringe plunger, and 70-μm strainer.
Place the strainer on the petri dish.
Vortex the tissue suspension thoroughly and pour it into the strainer.
Grind it with the syringe plunger thoroughly.
Wash the strainer with 5 mL of the isolation buffer.
Transfer the homogenate from the strainer into a new 15-mL tube.
Repeat the wash and transfer the homogenate to a new tube.

Centrifuge the tube at 4°C, 440 rcf for 5 min.
Separate cells from the myelin debris via Percoll density gradient centrifugation.
Prepare 30% and 70% Percoll solutions.
Remove the supernatant of the centrifugated homogenate, and resuspend the pellet with 5 mL of 30% Percoll solution.
Place a Pasteur pipette into the tube.
Add 3 mL of 70% Percoll solution below the 30% Percoll solution through the Pasteur pipette.
Centrifuge the tube at RT, 800 rcf for 20 min. Allow the centrifuge to come to a stop without applying the brakes.
Remove the myelin debris on the 70% Percoll layer.
Within the line between the 30% and 70% Percoll layers, take about 3 mL of media and transfer into a new 15-mL tube.
Add FACS buffer to a total volume of 15 mL and invert gently.
Centrifuge the tube at 4°C, 440 rcf for 5 min.
Remove red blood cells by ACK lysis buffer.
Remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the cell pellet with 1 mL of ACK lysis buffer, and incubate at RT for 5 min.
Add 1 mL of FACS buffer, and centrifuge at 4°C, 440 rcf for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the cell pellet with 1 mL of RPMI CM.
Filter cells with a sterilized 70-μm mesh. Then count the number of cells using trypan blue and a cell counter and store at 4°C.
Section 4. Single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNAseq) analysis for immune cells from the brain tumor microenvironment
Timing: ∼72 h
This section explains how to perform scRNAseq analysis.
Note: The platform used to perform scRNAseq analysis could vary depending on preferences, and details for analysis could be different depending on the platform. We followed the manufacturer’s protocol and there are more details for this procedure. The protocol is provided from the manufacturer’s website (https://support.10xgenomics.com/single-cell-gene-expression/library-prep/doc/user-guide-chromium-single-cell-3-reagent-kits-user-guide-v3-chemistry[href=https://support.10xgenomics.com/single-cell-gene-expression/library-prep/doc/user-guide-chromium-single-cell-3-reagent-kits-user-guide-v3-chemistry]).

Antibody staining for immune cell preparation.
Transfer an adequate amount of cells into a 5-mL round-bottom polystyrene tube.
Centrifuge the tube at 4°C, 440 rcf for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant and add 100 μL (per million cells) of Fc block diluted in FACS buffer to a 1:100 ratio.
Incubate on ice for 20 min in the dark.
Add 1 mL of FACS buffer to the sample and centrifuge at 4°C, 440 rcf for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant and add 100 μL (per million cells) of anti-CD45 antibody diluted in FACS buffer at a 1:200 ratio.
Cells from C57BL/6 mice are stained with anti-CD45.2 antibody.
Cells from LSL-EGFRviii mice are stained with anti-CD45.1 antibody.
Incubate the sample on ice for 30 min in the dark.
Add 1 mL of FACS buffer to the sample and centrifuge at 4°C, 440 rcf for 5 min. Repeat this step once.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the cell pellet in 1–2 mL of FACS buffer.
To exclude dead cells, add 5 μL (per million cells) of 7-AAD (BioLegend) and incubate for 5–10 min in the dark prior to flow sorting.
Sort ∼1–2 × 105 7-AAD-CD45+ immune cells using the FACS Aria II (BD Biosciences) into a new 15-mL tube containing RPMI CM.
Centrifuge at 4°C, 440 rcf for 5 min, and remove the supernatant being careful not to touch the cell pellet.
Resuspend the cell pellet with cold PBS to a concentration of 700–1200 cells/μL.
Note: The range of optimal cell concentration is chosen based on the manufacturer’s protocol.
Prepare a master mix for barcoding that contains RT Reagent, Template Switch Oligo, Reducing Agent B, and RT Enzyme C. Add the appropriate volume of nuclease-free water depending on the cell concentration.

Install a Chromium Chip B in a 10× Chip Holder and add 50% glycerol solution into the unused chip wells (row #1: 75 μL, row #2: 40 μL, row #3: 280 μL).
Prepare the Gel Bead strip by vortexing for 30 s in a 10× Vortex Adaptor.
Mix the cell suspension with the corresponding volume of master mix for barcoding.
Load the corresponding sample onto the Chromium Chip without introducing bubbles.
row #1: 75 μL of mixture for cell suspension and master mix for barcoding.
row #2: 40 μL of Gel Beads.
row #3: 280 μL of Partitioning Oil.
Attach the 10× Gasket to the Chromium Chip and place in the tray of the Controller.
Start the Chromium Single Cell B program.
After the run finishes, transfer 100 μL of gel based-in emulsions (GEMs) in the Recovery wells in the top row into a tube strip on ice.
Incubate in a thermal cycler with the following steps: 53°C for 45 min, 85°C for 5 min, and hold at 4°C.
Note: After this process, the sample can be stored at 4°C for up to 72 h or at −20°C for up to week.
Purify the first-strand cDNA from the reaction mixture.
Add 125 μL of Recovery Agent to each sample at RT without pipette mixing or vortexing, and then wait 60 s.
Note: This biphasic mixture consists of Recovery Agent/Partitioning Oil (pink, lower layer) and aqueous phase (clear, upper layer).
Carefully remove 125 μL of Recovery Agent/Partitioning Oil from the bottom.
Prepare Dynabeads Cleanup Mix containing Cleanup Buffer, Dynabeads MyOne SILANE, and Reducing Agent B.
Note: Dynabeads MyOne SILANE should be thoroughly mixed by vortexing before using.
Add 200 μL of Dynabeads Cleanup Mix to each sample and mix by pipetting.

Incubate for 10 min at RT and mix again at ∼5 min after the start of incubation by pipetting.
During the incubation, prepare Elution Solution I containing elution buffer, 10% Tween-20, and Reducing Agent B with vortexing and spin down.
After incubation, place the sample on the High position of a 10× Magnetic Separator until the solution clears.
Remove the supernatant and wash twice with 80% ethanol.
Place the sample on the Low position of the separator and remove the remaining ethanol by air drying for 1 min.
Remove the sample from the separator, add 35.5 μL of Elution Solution I, and incubate for 2 min at RT.
Place the sample on the Low position of the separator until the solution clears.
Transfer 35 μL of the sample into a new tube strip.
Amplify the cDNA with Amp Mix and cDNA primers using a thermal cycler programmed with the following protocol:
table:files/protocols_protocol_1886_13.csv
Note: The number of cycles is dependent on the number of cells inputted.
Note: After this process, the sample can be stored at 4°C for up to 72 h.
Clean up cDNA using SPRIselect.
Add SPRIselect reagent (0.6×) to each sample and incubate for 5 min at RT.
Place on the High position of the separator until the solution clears.
Remove the supernatant and wash twice with 80% ethanol.
Place the sample on the Low position of the separator and remove the remaining ethanol by air drying for 2 min.
Remove the sample from the separator, and elute with elution buffer for 2 min at RT.
Place the sample on the High position of the separator until the solution clears.
Transfer 40 μL of sample into a new tube strip.

Note: After this process, the sample can be stored at 4°C for up to 72 h or at −20°C for up to 4 weeks.
To perform a quality check and quantify the cDNA, dilute 1 μL of sample at 1:10 ratio using DW and use the Agilent High Sensitivity DNA Kit with Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer.
Note: This step is followed by the manufacturer’s protocol provided in the website (https://www.agilent.com/cs/library/usermanuals/public/HighSensitivity_DNA_KG.pdf.pdf[href=https://www.agilent.com/cs/library/usermanuals/public/HighSensitivity_DNA_KG.pdf.pdf]).
Note: Agilent TapeStation High Sensitivity D5000 ScreenTape can also be utilized for this process.
Proceed with cDNA fragmentation, end repair, and A-tailing by adding the Fragmentation Buffer and Fragmentation Enzyme and then incubating in a thermal cycler with the following protocol: hold at 4°C, 5 min at 32°C, 30 min at 65°C, and hold at 4°C.
Use the SPRIselect reagent to clean up the sample.
Add 30 μL of 0.6× SPRIselect reagent to each sample and incubate for 5 min at RT.
Place on the High position of the separator until the solution clears.
Transfer 75 μL of supernatant to a new tube strip.
Add 10 μL of 0.8× SPRIselect reagent to each sample and incubate for 5 min at RT.
Place on the High position of the separator until the solution clears.
Remove the supernatant and wash twice with 80% ethanol.
Remove from the separator and elute with elution buffer for 2 min at RT.
Place on the High position of the separator until the solution clears.
Transfer sample to a new tube strip.
For adaptor ligation, incubate each sample with the mix containing Ligation Buffer, DNA Ligase, and Adaptor Oligos in a thermal cycler with the following protocol: 15 min at 20°C and hold at 4°C.
Repeat the clean-up process using 0.8× SPRIselect reagent and the separator.

For sample indexing, incubate each sample with a PCR mix containing Amp Mix, SI Primer, and an individual Chromium i7 Sample Index on a thermal cycler with the following protocol:
table:files/protocols_protocol_1886_14.csv
Note: The number of cycles is dependent on the amount of cDNA inputted.
Repeat the clean-up process using 0.6× SPRIselect reagent and the separator.
To assess the quality of library construction, dilute 1 μL of sample at a 1:10 ratio using DW and use the Agilent High Sensitivity DNA Kit with Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer.
Note: Agilent TapeStation High Sensitivity D5000 ScreenTape can also be utilized for this process.
To sequence the library, use the Illumina HiSeq X Ten sequencing system with the HiSeq X Ten Reagent Kit v2.5 and PhiX Control v3 with the recommended cycle conditions: Read 1: 28 cycles, i7 index: 8 cycles, i5 index: cycles, and Read 2: 91 cycles.
A 10× Chromium Cell Ranger can be used according to the manufacturer’s instructions to generate three files for sequencing data: bacordes.tsv, features.tsv, and matrix.mtx.
Create Seurat objects and verify the quality of samples.
Read sequencing data using the Read10X function.
Create Seurat objects using the CreateSeuratObject function.
Check the level of nFeature_RNA, nCount_RNA, and mitochondrial gene expression.
Isolate quality-controlled objects using the Subset function.
Normalize data using the NormalizeData function.
Identify features of objects using the FindVariableFeatures function.
Combine objects.
Find anchorsets using the FindIntegrationAnchors function.
Combine anchorsets using the IntegrateData function.
Cluster and visualize the data.
Scale features in the dataset using the ScaleData function.
Set “integrated” as a default assay.
Reduce dataset dimension using the RunPCA function.
Reduce dataset using the RunUMAP function.
Construct a shared nearest neighbor graph from the dataset using the FindNeighbors function.
Identify clusters of cells by shared nearest neighbors using the FindClusters function.

Visualize clusters using the DimPlot function (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1886-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. scRNAseq analysis of spontaneous and injection brain tumor model
(A–E) EGFRvIII-LSL mice pups were injected with sgRNA-containing vectors. When mice displayed a hunched posture, tissues were obtained. We harvested tissues at 20 days after intracranial injection of GL261 cells into the C57BL/6J mice. Single cell suspensions were isolated and single cell-RNA sequencing (scRNAseq) was performed. (A) UMAP projection of whole samples. (B) UMAP projections split by batch. (C) UMAP projection of different samples. (D) Dot plots of marker genes for identifying cell type. (E) Heat map of relative proportions of immune cell types among samples.
Compare the distribution of clusters among different batches (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B and 4C).
Determine the identity of clusters using cellular markers (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]D).
Compare the distribution of immune cells in the tumor tissues using a heat map (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]E).
Section 5. Flow cytometric analysis for immune cells from the brain tumor microenvironment
Timing: 12–24 h
This section explains how to analyze immune cells using flow cytometry (continued from Section 3. Isolation of single cells from the brain tumor microenvironment[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec3.3]). We used the FACS Fortessa X-20 to acquire cells and FlowJo software for analysis. The flow cytometers and software used for this analysis can vary depending on the user’s preferences.
Transfer 1 × 106 cells from each sample to a new 5-mL polystyrene tube.
Centrifuge the tube at 4°C, 440 rcf for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant and add 100 μL (per million cells) of Fc block diluted in FACS buffer at a 1:100 ratio.
Incubate on ice for 20 min in the dark.
Add 1 mL of FACS buffer to the sample and centrifuge at 4°C, 440 rcf for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant and add 100 μL (per million cells) of antibody mixture.

Cells from C57BL/6 mice are stained with anti-CD45.2 antibody.
Cells from LSL-EGFRviii mice are stained with anti-CD45.1 antibody.
Incubate on ice for 30 min in the dark.
Add 1 mL of FACS buffer to the sample and centrifuge at 4°C, 440 rcf for 5 min. Repeat this step once.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the cell pellet in 300 μL of FACS buffer.
Before analysis, add 5 μL of propidium iodide solution to the sample and incubate for 5 min.
Acquire cells using the FACS Fortessa X-20 machine (or other flow cytometer).
Export .fcs data and load to FlowJo (or other software) for analysis.
Identify cell types using cell lineage markers.
Example data are shown in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1886-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Flow cytometric analysis of the spontaneous brain tumor model
(A–E) At 16 weeks after spontaneous tumor induction, the mice were sacrificed and single cells were isolated from tumor tissues. Cells were analyzed by flow cytometry. (A) Cell number of microglia (CD11b+CD45lo), CD11b+ tumor-inflitrating leukocytes (TILs; CD11b+CD45hi), and lymphoid TILs (CD11b-CD45hi). (B) The number of γδ T cells (CD45hiCD11b-CD3ε+γδTCR+). (C) The number of CD8 T cells (CD45hiCD11b-CD8a+) (left) and CD4 T cells (CD45hiCD11b-CD4+) (right). (D) The percentage of naïve (CD62L+CD44-), central memory (CM; CD62L+CD44+), double negative (DN; CD62L-CD44-), and CD8 and (E) CD4 effector T cells (CD62L-CD44+). Data were analyzed by the two-tailed unpaired Student’s t test. ∗P<0.05, ∗∗P<0.01, ∗∗∗P<0.001. Error bars represent the mean ± standard error of the mean.
